Award.AwardTitle: Chemical Pathways for Controlling Polymorphism in Nanoscale Metal Chalcogenides
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award by the Solid State and Materials Chemistry (SSMC) program supports work by Professor Raymond Schaak at the Pennsylvania State University to identify and understand the chemical factors that lead to the formation of nanoparticulate non-equilibrium phases of transition metal sulfides and selenides, including ZnS, ZnSe, and several sulfides and selenides of Co, Ni, and Mn. The targeted materials exhibit a variety of interesting and useful electronic, magnetic, and optical properties, and their crystal structures directly impact their properties. This research builds on emerging capabilities for synthesizing non-equilibrium phases using chemical routes that form nanoparticulate solids in solution from soluble precursors. Such discoveries are usually serendipitous, involving a large number of variables and complex in-situ chemistry. In this project, Prof. Schaak's group investigates the reaction pathways by which these new solids form to reveal important insights that can help lead to a predictive framework for selectively targeting desired non-equilibrium phases based on fundamental chemical principles.

The crystal structure that an extended solid adopts plays a key role in defining its properties. At the same time, the techniques and conditions used to synthesize a solid can help to influence the crystal structure that it forms. This project seeks to identify and understand the chemical factors that selectively lead to the formation of one crystal structure instead of others in a system where multiple structures may be accessible. These insights will help researchers to more predictably synthesize desired materials with targeted properties. This project provides multi-disciplinary training to a diverse group of graduate and undergraduate students. Emphasis is placed on integrating teams of undergraduate researchers directly into the technical goals of the project through specially designed undergraduate research projects.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The arrangement of atoms in a crystal plays a key role in defining its properties. It is therefore important to be able to control the crystal structure of a material, along with other property-defining features. Many materials systems can have more than one crystal structure for a given composition. While each crystal structure can have distinct properties, there is one structure that is most stable, and this is the structure that is easiest to synthesize. The ability to predictably synthesize other less-stable structures can open the door to producing new materials having properties that would not otherwise be achievable. This project focused on developing the fundamental knowledge necessary to access such less-stable crystal structures for nanoscale metal sulfide, selenide, and telluride (chalcogenide) systems that are useful for their potential catalytic, magnetic, electronic, and optical properties. The key scientific outcomes advanced capabilities in the design and synthesis of complex nanocrystal systems with targeted features, including crystal structures, compositions, and shapes.

Several types of metal oxide and metal chalcogenide nanocrystals were synthesized, both to gain new insights into how they form and to use in subsequent studies of chemical reactivity. Chemical reactions were also developed and studied to transform nanocrystals from precursors to products, allowing pre-programming of key materials features including crystal structure, composition, and shape. Nanocrystal products that maintain the crystal structure and shape of the precursor nanocrystals but none of the original constituent elements could be accessed by coupling together sequential anion and cation exchange reactions of metal oxide and sulfide nanocrystals. Control over morphology and composition was therefore fully decoupled in these model systems, providing new synthetic guidelines for independently targeting desired features in complex nanocrystals. Similar cation exchange reactions were also used to produce crystal structures of nanocrystalline metal sulfides that are not typically accessible. Key structural features of a copper sulfide phase were retained upon cation exchange to produce related manganese and cobalt sulfides, providing important new protocols and guidelines for rationally targeting the formation of crystal structures that are metastable in bulk systems. Finally, colloidal nanostructures of several transition metal dichalcogenides were synthesized and studied. Notably, molybdenum ditelluride formed a crystal structure that is known to be metastable. The morphology, which consists of aggregated and polycrystalline few-layer nanosheets having nanoscale grain boundaries, helped to make the metastable structure accessible, providing important guidelines for targeting and stabilizing multiple distinct crystal structures in the same material system. This project produced new knowledge for precisely targeting desired nanocrystal features in systems that are relevant to many emerging technologies. This project also provided multi-disciplinary training to a team of graduate and undergraduate students, seeded new collaborations that brought together scientists from different disciplines, and facilitated outreach and professional development opportunities for students.

 


Last Modified: 11/29/2016
Modified by: Raymond Schaak
